spanishExample: Esto es demasiado *spicy,* ¡siempre pones muchas *spices!*
englishTranslation: This is too spicy, you always put a lot of spices(f)!
vocabIncluded: pones: put, you put (Poner, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Las pongo con cariño donde él las puso antes.
englishTranslation: I’m putting them(f) with affection where he put them before.
vocabIncluded: las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
pongo: put, I put (Poner, present, 1st person)
puso: put, he/she/it put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Les tengo cariño a las personas que ponen las cosas donde tienen que ir.
englishTranslation: I’m fond of the people who put things where they have to go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
ponen:put, they put (Poner, present, 3rd person plural)
tenerle cariño a alguien: to be fond of someone (idiom)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¡Tienes suerte de que no *I called* a la policía!
englishTranslation: You’re lucky that I didn’t call the police!
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: No nos ponemos eso porque no estamos a gusto.
englishTranslation: We don’t wear that because we aren’t comfortable.
vocabIncluded: ponemos: put, we put (Poner, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No quiero que pongas esas cosas en la casa si tienes miedo.
englishTranslation: I don’t want you to put those things in the house if you are afraid.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pongas: put, you put(Poner, subjunctive, 2nd person plural)

spanishExample: Nuestro equipo tiene que ponerse *the uniform.*
englishTranslation: Our team has to wear the uniform.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Por favor póngase esto si nos tiene cariño.
englishTranslation: (formal) Please wear this if you are fond of us.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
póngase: put on / become (Ponerse, formal imperative)
tenerle cariño a alguien: to be fond of someone (idiom)

spanishExample: Pusieron eso ahí para *show* su amor.
englishTranslation: They put(preterite) that there to show their love.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
pusieron: put, they put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Quiero que pongan esto exactamente donde quiero.
englishTranslation: I want them to put this exactly where I want.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
ponga: put, I put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Quizás yo lo ponga aquí para que ella no lo ponga.
englishTranslation: Maybe I will put it here so that she doesn’t put it.
vocabIncluded: ponga: put, I put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person)
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Realmente lo hice con mucho cariño.
englishTranslation: I really did it with a lot of affection.

spanishExample: Siempre pone esto aquí y tengo miedo.
englishTranslation: He always puts this here and I’m afraid.
vocabIncluded: pone: puts, he/she/it puts (Poner, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Supone que es demasiado para ellos.
englishTranslation: He supposes that it’s too much for them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supone: supposes, he/she/it supposes (Suponer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Supone que no tengo miedo de esas cosas.
englishTranslation: He supposes that I’m not afraid of those things.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supone: supposes, he/she/it supposes (Suponer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Supongo que no quiere que ponga esto aquí.
englishTranslation: I guess she doesn’t want me to put this here.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponga: put, I put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person)
supongo: suppose, I suppose (Suponer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Supuse que la policía estaría aquí y que yo estaría a gusto.
englishTranslation: I supposed that the police would be here and that I’d be comfortable.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
estaría: "would be", "I would be" (Estar, conditional, 1st person)
estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)
supuse: supposed, I supposed (Suponer, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Supuse que no tenía clase hoy porque estaba *snowing.*
englishTranslation: I guessed that I didn’t have class today because it was snowing.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supuse: supposed, I supposed (Suponer, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Tienes que ponerte en mi lugar.
englishTranslation: You have to put yourself in my shoes.
vocabIncluded: ponerse en el lugar de alguien: "to put oneself in someone's shoes" (idiom)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes suerte porque tienes paz.
englishTranslation: You’re lucky because you have peace.

spanishExample: Cariño, no tienes que suponer eso.
englishTranslation: Darling, you don’t have to suppose that.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Cariño, supongo que no tienen que ponerse tristes por esto.
englishTranslation: Darling, I guess they don’t have to get sad because of this.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
supongo: suppose, I suppose (Suponer, present, 1st person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Casi lo hiciste bien, pero tienes que ponerlo aquí en vez.
englishTranslation: You almost did it right, but you have to put it here instead.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: El equipo lo ha puesto en la casa.
englishTranslation: The team has put it in the house.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Pon eso aquí para que podamos tener paz!
englishTranslation: Put that here so we can have peace!
vocabIncluded: podamos: "be able", "we be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Supongo que mi amigo quiere que lo pongamos en *the living room.*
englishTranslation: I guess my friend wants us to put it in the living room.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pongamos: put, we put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person plural)
supongo: suppose, I suppose (Suponer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¡Qué suerte que su amor sea tan grande!
englishTranslation: How lucky that your(plural) love is so big!
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb

spanishExample: Mi clase y yo pusimos nuestro trabajo en *the desk* de la *teacher.*
englishTranslation: My class and I put(past) our work on the teacher’s(f) desk.
vocabIncluded: pusimos: put, we put (Poner, preterite, 1st person plural)
